Well, said he, my mate Bill would be called the captain, as like  as not.
Well, mother was upstairs with father and I was laying the  breakfasttable against the captains return when the parlour door  opened and a man stepped in on whom I had never set my eyes before.
Well, then, said he, this is the berth for me.
Well, then, said he, you hold the basin; and with that he took his  lancet and opened a vein.
Well, then, you get on a horse, and go towell, yes,  I will!
Well, Ive heard of him myself, in England, said the doctor.
Well, sir, I thought I had only found a cook,       but it was a crew I had discovered.
Well, squire, said Dr.
Well, Captain Smollett, what have you to say?
Well, sir, said the captain, better speak plain, I believe, even at  the risk of offence.
Well, gentlemen, are you determined to go on this cruise?
Well, gentlemen, continued the captain, I dont know who has this  map; but I make it a point, it shall be kept secret even from me and Mr.
Well, says the doctor, we shall see.
Well, said the other, but all the other moneys gone now, aint it?
Well, and where are they now?
Well, hes dead now hisself; he knows the long and short on it now;  and if ever a rough hand come to port, it was Billy.
Well, gentlemen, said the captain, the best that I can say is not  much.
Well, I was in another ship three years back, and we sighted this  island.
Well, Jim, three years have I been here, and not a bite of Christian  diet from that day to this.
Well, I said, I dont understand one word that youve been saying.
Well, on the knoll, and enclosing the spring, they had clapped a  stout loghouse fit to hold two score of people on a pinch and loopholed  for musketry on either side.
Well, said I, that may be so, and so be it; all the more reason that  I should hurry on and join my friends.
Well, said I, I believe I understand.
Well, thats  for Ben Gunn!
Well, well, capn, returned the seacook, sitting down as he was  bidden on the sand, youll have to give me a hand up again, thats all.
Well, here it is, said Silver.

Well, so short had been the interval that when I  found my feet again all was in the same posture, the fellow with the red  nightcap still halfway over, another still just showing his head above  the top of the stockade.

Well, now that I had found the boat, you would have thought I had had  enough of truantry for once, but in the meantime I had taken another  notion and become so obstinately fond of it that I would have carried  it out, I believe, in the teeth of Captain Smollett himself.

Well, now, thought I to myself, it is plain I must lie where I am and  not disturb the balance; but it is plain also that I can put the paddle  over the side and from time to time, in smooth places, give her a shove  or two towards land.
Well, said I, Ive come aboard to take possession of this ship,  Mr.
Well, as it seemed to me, there was some sense in this.
Well, I reckon its about the blessed same to me, shipmate, he  replied; so its strong, and plenty of it, whats the odds?
Well, now I tell you, I never seen good come  o goodness yet.

Well, while things stood thus, suddenly the HISPANIOLA struck,  staggered, ground for an instant in the sand, and then, swift as a  blow, canted over to the port side till the deck stood at an angle  of fortyfive degrees and about a puncheon of water splashed into the  scupper holes and lay, in a pool, between the deck and bulwark.
Well, come, I take that friendly.
Well, says I, growing a bit bolder, if Im to choose, I declare I  have a right to know whats what, and why youre here, and where my  friends are.
Well, says the doctor, lets bargain.
Well, said I, I am not such a fool but I know pretty well what I have  to look for.
Well, youre a gay lot to look at, anyway.
Well, what is it, anyway?
Well, I reckon  thats worth having too.
Well, step up here, Dick, and let me  see your tongue.

Well, he added after he had dosed them round and they had taken  his prescriptions, with really laughable humility, more like charity  schoolchildren than bloodguilty mutineers and pirateswell, thats  done for today.
Well, thats my first concession, added the doctor.
Well, I reckon he  was blue.
Well, thats so, he said.

im.sentence: Im on your side  now, hand and glove; and I shouldnt wish for to see the party weakened,  let alone yourself, seeing as I know what I owes you.
Im with you, sir, said he.
Im risking my life and the lives of these good gentlemen every  second.
Im poor Ben Gunn, I am; and I havent spoke with a  Christian these three years.
Im fifty, mark you; once back from this cruise, I set up  gentleman in earnest.
Im a plain man; rum  and bacon and eggs is what I want, and that head up there for to watch  ships off.

Im not a doctor only; Im a magistrate; and if I catch a breath  of complaint against you, if its only for a piece of incivility like  tonights, Ill take effectual means to have you hunted down and routed  out of this.
Im to be a  poor, crawling beggar, sponging for rum, when I might be rolling in a  coach!
Im bound  Ill be good, and I see the way to.
Im not strong enough, and I dont like the job; and there he lies, for  me, said I.
Im all for argyment; I  never seen good come out o threatening.
Im capn here because Im the best man by a long seamile.
Im off to seek it for you, and that itself will show you if I  speak at random.
Im Ben Gunn, I am, replied the maroon, wriggling like an eel in his  embarrassment.

mostly.sentence: Mostly  he would not speak when spoken to, only look up sudden and fierce and  blow through his nose like a foghorn; and we and the people who came  about our house soon learned to let him be.

often.sentence: Often I have heard the house  shaking with Yohoho, and a bottle of rum, all the neighbours joining  in for dear life, with the fear of death upon them, and each singing  louder than the other to avoid remark.

Often enough when the first  of the month came round and I applied to him for my wage, he would only  blow through his nose at me and stare me down, but before the week was  out he was sure to think better of it, bring me my fourpenny piece, and  repeat his orders to look out for the seafaring man with one leg.

dreadful.sentence: Dreadful stories  they wereabout hanging, and walking the plank, and storms at sea, and  the Dry Tortugas, and wild deeds and places on the Spanish Main.

livesey.sentence: Livesey shook hands with me through the stockade, nodded to  Silver, and set off at a brisk pace into the wood.
Livesey take the north side,  if you please; Jim, the east; Gray, west.
Livesey  had communicated my request, for the next thing that I heard was the  captain giving an order to Job Anderson, and all hands were piped on  deck.
Livesey called me to his  side.
Livesey were talking together on  the quarterdeck, and anxious as I was to tell them my story, I durst  not interrupt them openly.
Livesey were seated together,  finishing a quart of ale with a toast in it, before they should go  aboard the schooner on a visit of inspection.
Livesey will not like  that.
Livesey sat, pipe in hand, on either side of a  bright fire.

Livesey came  late one afternoon to see the patient, took a bit of dinner from my  mother, and went into the parlour to smoke a pipe until his horse should  come down from the hamlet, for we had no stabling at the old Benbow.
Livesey I began.
Livesey in?
Livesey fairly slapped his thigh, and the squire cried Bravo!
Livesey had kindly motioned me to come round from the  sidetable, where I had been eating, to enjoy the sport of the search.
Livesey as he passed on.
Livesey with delight.
Livesey cut in.
Livesey in the rush for the weather bow.
Livesey mad?
Livesey over the ships  side.
Livesey was by this time across the stockade and pretty near the  cook, and I could hear the alteration in his voice as he said, Not  Jim?
Livesey cheerily.

suddenly.sentence: Suddenly a kind of brightness fell about me.
Suddenly hethe captain,  that isbegan to pipe up his eternal song:              Fifteen men on the dead mans chest               Yohoho, and a bottle of rum!
Suddenly the captain spoke up again, and I thought his voice was a  little changed.

Suddenly the schooner in front of me gave a violent yaw, turning,  perhaps, through twenty degrees; and almost at the same moment one  shout followed another from on board; I could hear feet pounding on  the companion ladder and I knew that the two drunkards had at last been  interrupted in their quarrel and awakened to a sense of their disaster.
Suddenly the HISPANIOLA came right into the wind.

drink.sentence: Drink and the devil had done for the rest               Yohoho, and a bottle of rum!
Drink and the devil had done for the rest                Yohoho, and a bottle of rum!

Drink and the devil had done  for the rest, with a vengeance, although, to be sure, we were not quite  in so bad a case as that other ship they sang about:         With one man of her crew alive,       What put to sea with seventyfive.

liveseys;.sentence: Liveseys; he went on as before speaking  clear and kind and drawing briskly at his pipe between every word or  two.
Liveseys; the rest were revenue officers, whom he had met by the  way, and with whom he had had the intelligence to return at once.

says.sentence: Says he, Capn Silver, youre sold out.
says Captain Smollett as cool as can be.

says the doctor; and when the ruffian had  told him, with another oath, that this was so, I have only one thing to  say to you, sir, replies the doctor, that if you keep on drinking rum,  the world will soon be quit of a very dirty scoundrel!

liveseys.sentence: Liveseys horse came to the door and he rode away, but  the captain held his peace that evening, and for many evenings to come.

come.sentence: Come in, Jim, said the captain.
Come away, Hawkins, he would say; come and have a yarn with John.
Come high  water, all hands take a pull upon the line, and off she comes as sweet  as natur.
Come back to my dooty, sir, returned Silver.

well.sentence: Well all swing and sundry for your  bungling.
Well now, Im no scholar, and youre a  lad as can read and figure, and to put it straight, do you take it as a  dead man is dead for good, or do he come alive again?
Well now, you look here, that was a good lay of yours last  night.
Well armed, they stole  out of the stockade, but it proved a useless mission.
Well then, I mean this  squire and doctor shall find the stuff, and help us to get it aboard,  by the powers.
Well now, I tell you, Im not a boasting man, and you  seen yourself how easy I keep company, but when I was quartermaster,  LAMBS wasnt the word for Flints old buccaneers.
Well have favourable  winds, a quick passage, and not the least difficulty in finding the  spot, and money to eat, to roll in, to play duck and drake with ever  after.
Well do them yet, and he sprang  to his feet.
Well put it, for argument  like, that your captain has a cut on one cheekand well put it, if you  like, that that cheeks the right one.
Well have that chest  open, if we die for it.
Well take Redruth, Joyce, and Hunter.
Well now, if you want to know,  Ill tell you when.
Well never get ashore at this rate, said I.
Well have to do sentrygo and ease off a point or so on the  rum.
Well  divide stores with you, man for man; and Ill give my affydavy, as  before to speak the first ship I sight, and send em here to pick you  up.
Well now, look here, Ill answer these four pints; one after another  Ill answer em.

Well now, you all  know what I wanted, and you all know if that had been done that wed  a been aboard the HISPANIOLA this night as ever was, every man of us  alive, and fit, and full of good plumduff, and the treasure in the hold  of her, by thunder!

ah,.sentence: Ah, said Silver, it were fortunate for me that I had Hawkins here.
Ah, the others!
Ah, well, he did, though, said he.
Ah, hed  be a lucky one as knowed that!
Ah, Jim, Jim, I reckon Ive missed  stays!
Ah, he was  the man to have a headpiece, was Flint!
Ah, Silver!
Ah, well, said he, but I hadremarkable pious.
Ah, says he, this here is a sweet spot, this islanda sweet spot for  a lad to get ashore on.
Ah,  they was a sweet crew, they was!
Ah, but Ive lived easy  in the meantime, never denied myself o nothing heart desires, and slep  soft and ate dainty all my days but when at sea.
Ah, Bill, Bill, we have seen a sight of times, us two, since  I lost them two talons, holding up his mutilated hand.
Ah, well!
Ah, he looked a shark, he did!
Ah, shes a handsome craft, she is, the cook would say, and give her  sugar from his pocket, and then the bird would peck at the bars and  swear straight on, passing belief for wickedness.
Ah, you may be sure of  yourself in old Johns ship.
Ah, Jim, youll bless your stars, you will, you was  the first that found me!
Ah, said he, so you would.
Ah, says he, you can go ashore, if you like,  and stay, he says; but as for the ship, shell beat up for more, by  thunder!
Ah, said he, thats the hitch, for sure.
Ah, theres Jim!
Ah, you thats  youngyou and me might have done a power of good together!
Ah, there!
Ah, its a fine danceIm with you thereand looks mighty  like a hornpipe in a ropes end at Execution Dock by London town, it  does.
Ah,  well, theres a deal to say to number three.
Ah, there, said Morgan, that comed of spiling Bibles.
Ah, well, my son, you praise your stars hes dead, said Silver.
Ah, Merry, remarked Silver, standing for capn again?

bill,.sentence: Bill, said the stranger in a voice that I thought he had tried to make  bold and big.

thats.sentence: Thats your seven  hundred thousand pounds, is it?
Thats a true word.
Thats for number one, cried the accused, wiping the sweat from his  brow, for he had been talking with a vehemence that shook the house.
Thats better odds than we had at starting.
Thats what I think of ye.
Thats enough, capn, shouted Long John cheerily.
Thats what he said.
Thats what all you gentlemen split on,  first and last.
Thats as you please, sir, said the captain.
Thats a summons, mate.
Thats you, Bill, returned Black Dog, youre in the right of it,  Billy.
Thats short and sweet.
Thats a good man, captain, said the doctor.
Thats my belief.
Thats what I say.
Thats what I call  business.
Thats what it  begun with, but it went furthern that; and so my mother told me, and  predicked the whole, she did, the pious woman!
Thats what I mean,  replied the captain.
Thats as may be, replied the captain.
Thats your sort, is it?
Thats fair enow, said the old man Morgan.

jim,.sentence: Jim, he whispered, take that, and stand by for trouble.
Jim, he said at length, you saw that seafaring man today?
Jim, says he, rum; and as he spoke, he reeled a little, and caught  himself with one hand against the wall.
Jim, he said, are you afraid of blood?
Jim, he said, youre the only one here thats worth anything, and you  know Ive been always good to you.
Jim, Jim, says he, quite pleased apparently.
Jim, says he, I reckon were fouled, you and me, and well have to  sign articles.

dear,.sentence: Dear, deary me, cried my mother, what a disgrace upon the house!

hawkins,.sentence: Hawkins, will you give me your word of honour as a young gentlemanfor  a young gentleman you are, although poor bornyour word of honour not  to slip your cable?
Hawkins, help yourself, and back to  your post to eat it, continued Captain Smollett.
Hawkins,  just you run upstairs to your husband and tell him, if possible, nothing  about it.
Hawkins, will you ring that bell?
Hawkins, I put prodigious faith in you, added the squire.
Hawkins, neither you nor I are much account at the shooting; well stand  by to load and bear a hand.
Hawkins, said he, in the dogwatch, down came Doctor Livesey with a  flag of truce.

heres.sentence: Heres this squire and doctor with a map and suchI dont know  where it is, do I?

Heres luck, A fair wind, and Billy Bones his  fancy, were very neatly and clearly executed on the forearm; and up  near the shoulder there was a sketch of a gallows and a man hanging from  itdone, as I thought, with great spirit.
Heres Capn FlintI calls my parrot Capn Flint, after the  famous buccaneerheres Capn Flint predicting success to our vyage.
Heres this poor old  innocent bird o mine swearing blue fire, and none the wiser, you may  lay to that.
Heres a firstrate seaman, Capn Smollett, sails the blessed ship for  us.
Heres  the compass; theres the tiptop pint o Skeleton Island, stickin  out like a tooth.

prophetic,.sentence: Prophetic, said the doctor, touching this picture with his finger.

first.sentence: First he recognized the doctor with  an unmistakable frown; then his glance fell upon me, and he looked  relieved.
First of all well try the book, observed the doctor.
First ship that ever I lost, said Captain Smollett.

First she loomed before me like a blot of something yet blacker than  darkness, then her spars and hull began to take shape, and the next  moment, as it seemed (for, the farther I went, the brisker grew the  current of the ebb), I was alongside of her hawser and had laid hold.
First and last, weve split upon Jim Hawkins!

bones.sentence: Bones    Thats not my name, he interrupted.

die,.sentence: die, and go  to your own place, like the man in the Bible.

doctors.sentence: Doctors is all swabs, he said; and that doctor there, why, what do  he know about seafaring men?

look,.sentence: Look, Jim, how my fingers fidges,  he continued in the pleading tone.

aye,.sentence: Aye, and so it were, cried Morgan, springing on his knees.
Aye, mates, said he, its lucky you have Barbecue to think for you  with this here head.
Aye, aye, sir, he took it, sure enough, returned Morgan.
Aye, said he, by thunder, but I wanted some o that!
Aye, aye, sir, answered the cook, and touching his forelock, he  disappeared at once in the direction of his galley.
Aye, aye, sir, cried the cook, in the passage.
Aye, aye, said he, thats some better, sure enough.

Aye, aye, mates, said Long John, who was standing by, with his crutch  under his arm, and at once broke out in the air and words I knew so  well:    Fifteen men on the dead mans chest    And then the whole crew bore chorus:    Yohoho, and a bottle of rum!
Aye, but you see, returned Ben Gunn, I didnt mean giving me a gate  to keep, and a suit of livery clothes, and such; thats not my mark,  Jim.
Aye, aye, said Silver; like enough; you wouldnt look to find a  bishop here, I reckon.
Aye, aye, returned Morgan; I mind him; he owed me money, he did, and  took my knife ashore with him.
Aye, that he did, observed another; now he raged, and now he hollered  for the rum, and now he sang.

lay.sentence: Lay to, and whistle for a  wind, thats my view.

hes.sentence: Hes seen  his slice of luck, has Dick, and you may lay to that.
Hes more a man than any pair of rats of you in  this here house, and what I say is this: let me see him thatll lay a  hand on himthats what I say, and you may lay to it.
Hes no common man, Barbecue, said the coxswain to me.
HES a bad un; but theres worse that put him  on.
Hes the cook, and the ringleader too.
Hes about the last of this crew for that, I take  it.
Hes dead, and he dont  walk, that I know; leastways, he wont walk by day, and you may lay to  that.

probably.sentence: Probably I should have told the whole story to  the doctor, for I was in mortal fear lest the captain should repent of  his confessions and make an end of me.

once,.sentence: Once, for instance, to our extreme wonder, he piped up to a  different air, a kind of country lovesong that he must have learned in  his youth before he had begun to follow the sea.

will.sentence: Will you have white or red?
Will you give me your hand,  my kind young friend, and lead me in?

sir,.sentence: Sir,  I could find it in my heart to blow the ship up.
Sir, said I, upon my word I dare not.
Sir, said I, it is for yourself I mean.
Sir, said Captain Smollett, with no intention to take offence, I  deny your right to put words into my mouth.
Sir, said the captain, if I risk another order, the whole shipll  come about our ears by the run.
Sir, said Silver, as between man and man, thats too much and too  little.

take.sentence: Take your hat, Hawkins, and well see  the ship.
Take the  Georges, Pew, and dont stand here squalling.
Take me in straight or Ill break your  arm.
Take a cutlass, him that dares, and Ill  see the colour of his inside, crutch and all, before that pipes empty.

lead.sentence: Lead me  straight up to him, and when Im in view, cry out, Heres a friend  for you, Bill.

boy,.sentence: Boy, take his left hand by the wrist and bring it near to my right.

ten.sentence: Ten to  one, if I were so foolhardy as to cut the HISPANIOLA from her anchor, I  and the coracle would be knocked clean out of the water.
Ten to one this is a trick.

six.sentence: Six fellows were to stay on  board, and the remaining thirteen, including Silver, began to embark.
Six they were, and six are we; and bones is what  they are now.

something.sentence: Something sang like an arrow through the air; I felt a blow  and then a sharp pang, and there I was pinned by the shoulder to the  mast.
Something must speedily  be resolved upon, and it occurred to us at last to go forth together  and seek help in the neighbouring hamlet.

bareheaded.sentence: Bareheaded as we were, we ran out at once in the gathering evening and  the frosty fog.

foryou.sentence: Foryou would have thought men would have been  ashamed of themselvesno soul would consent to return with us to the  Admiral Benbow.

liveseys,.sentence: Liveseys, of keeping me  beside himcould be carried out as we intended.
Liveseys, which lay in another  direction, not one would help us to defend the inn.

back.sentence: Back we will go, the way we came, and small  thanks to you big, hulking, chickenhearted men.

crossley,.sentence: Crossley,  to bring back our lawful money in.

draw.sentence: Draw down the blind, Jim, whispered my mother; they might come and  watch outside.

overcoming.sentence: Overcoming a strong repugnance, I tore open his shirt at the neck, and  there, sure enough, hanging to a bit of tarry string, which I cut with  his own gully, we found the key.

underneath.sentence: Underneath there  was an old boatcloak, whitened with seasalt on many a harbourbar.

mother,.sentence: Mother, said I, take the whole and lets be going, for I was sure  the bolted door must have seemed suspicious and would bring the whole  hornets nest about our ears, though how thankful I was that I had  bolted it, none could tell who had never met that terrible blind man.

far.sentence: Far more likely its the mutineers, I answered.
Far away out in the marsh there arose, all of a sudden, a sound  like the cry of anger, then another on the back of it; and then one  horrid, longdrawn scream.
Far too much, agreed the doctor.
Far less than halfway to the hamlet, very  little beyond the bottom of the hill, we must come forth into the  moonlight.

farther.sentence: Farther I could not move  her, for the bridge was too low to let me do more than crawl below it.

down.sentence: Down I sat to wait for darkness, and made a hearty meal of biscuit.
Down went Pew with a cry that  rang high into the night; and the four hoofs trampled and spurned him  and passed by.

promptly.sentence: Promptly afterwards, fresh sounds of  astonishment arose; the window of the captains room was thrown open  with a slam and a jingle of broken glass, and a man leaned out into the  moonlight, head and shoulders, and addressed the blind beggar on the  road below him.

pew,.sentence: Pew, he cried, theyve been before us.

someones.sentence: Someones turned the chest out  alow and aloft.

roared.sentence: roared Silver,  bending far forward from his position on the keg, with his pipe still  glowing in his right hand.
roared Merry, shaking it at Silver.

flints.sentence: Flints fist, I mean, he cried.

bills.sentence: Bills been overhauled  aready, said he; nothin left.

sure.sentence: Sure enough, they have  the ship.
Sure enough, they left their glim here, said the fellow from the  window.
Sure enough there was no hurry.

scatter.sentence: Scatter and look for them, dogs!

reiterated.sentence: reiterated Pew, striking  with his stick upon the road.

theres.sentence: Theres seven hundred thousand pound not a quarter of a  mile from here.
Theres a man, says Captain Smollett, nodding towards him, new to  this work.
Theres a strong scour with the ebb, he said, and this here passage  has been dug out, in a manner of speaking, with a spade.
Theres a strong current runs along the  south, and then away norard up the west coast.
Theres only one  man Im afraid of.
Theres Capn Trelawneywhats he to think?
Theres been too much blabbing already.
Theres the key; you fill a pannikin and bring it up.
Theres been blows too, and I  reckon your friends has had the best of it; and here they are ashore in  the old stockade, as was made years and years ago by Flint.
Theres a power of men been killed in this HISPANIOLAa  sight o poor seamen dead and gone since you and me took ship to  Bristol.
Theres  never a man looked me between the eyes and seen a good day aterwards,  Tom Morgan, you may lay to that.
Theres a breeze coming, Jim, said Silver, who had by this time  adopted quite a friendly and familiar tone.

dirk.sentence: Dirk was a fool and a coward from the  firstyou wouldnt mind him.

youd.sentence: Youd  be as rich as kings if you could find it, and you know its here, and  you stand there skulking.

hang.sentence: Hang it, Pew, weve got the doubloons!

squalling.sentence: Squalling was the word for it; Pews anger rose so high at these  objections till at last, his passion completely taking the upper hand,  he struck at them right and left in his blindness and his stick sounded  heavily on more than one.

him.sentence: Him as strikes first is my fancy; dead men dont bite;  thems my viewsamen, so be it.

Him they had deserted, whether in sheer panic  or out of revenge for his ill words and blows I know not; but there he  remained behind, tapping up and down the road in a frenzy, and groping  and calling for his comrades.
Him that wants shall get it.
Him and these six was alone here; he killed em,  every man; and this one he hauled here and laid down by compass, shiver  my timbers!

finally.sentence: Finally he took a wrong turn and ran a few  steps past me, towards the hamlet, crying, Johnny, Black Dog, Dirk,  and other names, you wont leave old Pew, matesnot old Pew!

one,.sentence: One,  tailing out behind the rest, was a lad that had gone from the hamlet to  Dr.

pew.sentence: Pew was that sort,  and he died a beggarman.

dance.sentence: Dance was  further complimented and at last dismissed.
Dance dismounted, and taking  me along with him, was admitted at a word into the house.
Dance told me to jump down and knock, and Dogger gave me a stirrup  to descend by.
Dance could make nothing of the scene.
Dance  stood there, as he said, like a fish out of water, and all he could do  was to dispatch a man to B to warn the cutter.

theyve.sentence: Theyve got off clean, and theres  an end.

only,.sentence: Only, he added, Im glad I trod on Master Pews corns, for by  this time he had heard my story.
Only, as we had no power to anchor and dared not  beach her till the tide had flowed a good deal farther, time hung on our  hands.

perfectly.sentence: Perfectly right, he interrupted very cheerily, perfectly righta  gentleman and a magistrate.

and,.sentence: And, he added, after a long pause, how do, Mr.
And, Jimlooking all round him and  lowering his voice to a whisperIm rich.
And, now I come to think of it, I might as  well ride round there myself and report to him or squire.
And, Jim, if you was to see Silver, you wouldnt go for to sell  Ben Gunn?

master.sentence: Master Pews  dead, when alls done; not that I regret it, but hes dead, you see, and  people will make it out against an officer of his Majestys revenue,  if make it out they can.

dance,.sentence: Dance, said the squire, you are a very noble fellow.
Dance, you have a good horse; take up this lad  behind you.
Dance, says he, very stately and condescending.

long.sentence: Long after the voice had died away they still stared in  silence, dreadfully, before them.
Long Johns eyes burned in his head as he took the chart, but by the  fresh look of the paper I knew he was doomed to disappointment.
Long John even got rid of two out of the six       or seven I had already engaged.
Long John Silver, he is       called, and has lost a leg; but that I regarded as       a recommendation, since he lost it in his       countrys service, under the immortal Hawke.
Long before it was done, Mr.
Long John Silver unearthed a very       competent man for a mate, a man named Arrow.
Long John told the story from first to last, with a great deal of spirit  and the most perfect truth.
Long  John was hard at work going from group to group, spending himself in  good advice, and as for example no man could have shown a better.

trelawney.sentence: Trelawney had followed the sea, and his knowledge made him  very useful, for he often took a watch himself in easy weather.

Trelawney (that, you will remember, was the squires name) had got up  from his seat and was striding about the room, and the doctor, as if to  hear the better, had taken off his powdered wig and sat there looking  very strange indeed with his own closecropped black poll.
Trelawney had taken up his residence at an inn far down the docks to  superintend the work upon the schooner.
Trelawney not told you of the buccaneers?
Trelawney was as cool as steel.
Trelawney on board the schooner died that same evening of his wound.

squire,.sentence: Squire, said he, when Dance has had his ale he must, of course, be  off on his Majestys service; but I mean to keep Jim Hawkins here to  sleep at my house, and with your permission, I propose we should have up  the cold pie and let him sup.

blackbeard.sentence: Blackbeard was a child to Flint.

ive.sentence: Ive half a mind to dine  first.
Ive taken a notion into my old numbskull, observed Silver.
Ive a head on my shoulders,  I have.
Ive always liked you, I have, for a lad of spirit,  and the picter of my own self when I was young and handsome.
Ive tried my fling, I have, and Ive  lost, and its you has the wind of me.
Ive a gauge on the keg, mind.
Ive had  amost enough o Capn Smollett; hes hazed me long enough, by thunder!
Ive seen his topsails with  these eyes, off Trinidad, and the cowardly son of a rumpuncheon that I  sailed with put backput back, sir, into Port of Spain.
Ive watered there with a trader I was cook  in.
Ive thought it all out in this here lonely island,  and Im back on piety.
Ive no manner of doubt that we can drub them, if you choose.
Ive  seen too many die since I fell in with you.
Ive  still a shot in my locker.
Ive got my piece o news, and thanky to him  for that; but its over and done.

have.sentence: Have I lived this many  years, and a son of a rum puncheon cock his hat athwart my hawse at the  latter end of it?

bones,.sentence: Bones, mate, No more rum, Off Palm Key he got itt, and some other  snatches, mostly single words and unintelligible.

offe.sentence: Offe Caraccas, now; you see, here was some unhappy vessel  boarded off that coast.

god.sentence: God help the poor souls that manned hercoral  long ago.

see.sentence: See here, now, Hawkins, said he, heres a blessed hard thing on a  man like me, now, aint it?
See what it is to be a traveller.

point.sentence: point of north inlet cape, bearing E.

hawkins.sentence: Hawkins over, we will, and well give him his share, to be sure, for  all his kindness.
Hawkins may stay one night with his       mother.

youll.sentence: Youll  please bear in mind its not my life only nowits that boys into the  bargain; and youll speak me fair, doctor, and give me a bit o hope to  go on, for the sake of mercy.
Youll make a note of this here also, doctor, says he, and the boyll  tell you how I saved his life, and were deposed for it too, and you  may lay to that.
Youll excuse me, I dare say,  but you remind me of that fable.
Youll make  a famous cabinboy, Hawkins.
Youll find I do my  duty.
Youll have your mouthful of rum tomorrow, and go hang.
Youll say so, Israel when you see, said Silver.
Youll bathe, and youll climb trees, and youll  hunt goats, you will; and youll get aloft on them hills like a goat  yourself.
Youll perhaps batten down your hatches till youre spoke to, my  friend, cried Silver truculently to this speaker.
Youll  all swing now, I reckon.
Youll be capn  next, I shouldnt wonder.

trelawney,.sentence: Trelawney, and the  embers smothered among sand.
Trelawney, Im surprised at you, sir.

Trelawney, being a very openhanded gentleman, as we all know, has just  asked me a word or two, and as I was able to tell him that every man on  board had done his duty, alow and aloft, as I never ask to see it done  better, why, he and I and the doctor are going below to the cabin to  drink YOUR health and luck, and youll have grog served out for you to  drink OUR health and luck.
Trelawney, said the doctor, Ill go with you; and Ill go bail for  it, so will Jim, and be a credit to the undertaking.
Trelawney, said the doctor, contrary to all my notions, I believed  you have managed to get two honest men on board with youthat man and  John Silver.
Trelawney, out and away, said I.
Trelawney, will you please pick me off one of these men, sir?
Trelawney, you  are the best shotyou and Gray will take this long north side, with the  five loopholes; its there the danger is.

jim.sentence: Jim and I shall stick together in the  meanwhile; youll take Joyce and Hunter when you ride to Bristol, and  from first to last, not one of us must breathe a word of what weve  found.
Jim here, said the doctor, can help us more than anyone.
Jim Hawkins is gone, was my first  thought.

sitting.sentence: Sitting by the fire in the housekeepers room, I  approached that island in my fancy from every possible direction; I  explored every acre of its surface; I climbed a thousand times to that  tall hill they call the Spyglass, and from the top enjoyed the most  wonderful and changing prospects.

obeying.sentence: Obeying this order, we  found, or rather I foundfor the gamekeeper was a poor hand at reading  anything but printthe following important news:         Old Anchor Inn, Bristol, March 1, 17         Dear LiveseyAs I do not know whether you       are at the hall or still in London, I send this in       double to both places.

redruth,.sentence: Redruth, said I, interrupting the letter, Dr.

growled.sentence: growled Dick, who was  evidently uneasy at the curse he had brought upon himself.

any.sentence: Any of the  undergamekeepers would gladly have changed places with him; but such  was not the squires pleasure, and the squires pleasure was like law  among them all.

nobody.sentence: Nobody interrupted me till I was done,  nor did any one of the three of them make so much as a movement, but  they kept their eyes upon my face from first to last.
Nobody but old Redruth would have dared so much as even  to grumble.
Nobody more welcome than yourself, my son.
Nobody in this here island ever heard of Darby, he muttered; not one  but us thats here.

get.sentence: Get  the captain and squire down to the cabin, and then make some pretence to  send for me.
Get back to your place for a lubber, Tom.

thither.sentence: Thither we had now to walk, and  our way, to my great delight, lay along the quays and beside the great  multitude of ships of all sizes and rigs and nations.

silver,.sentence: Silver, I should say, was allowed his entire liberty, and in spite of  daily rebuffs, seemed to regard himself once more as quite a privileged  and friendly dependent.
Silver, as he sat, took certain bearings with his compass.
Silver,  I said, I believe youre the best man here, and if things go to the  worst, Ill take it kind of you to let the doctor know the way I took  it.
Silver, agile as a monkey even without  leg or crutch, was on the top of him next moment and had twice buried  his knife up to the hilt in that defenceless body.

Silver, said the other manand I observed he was not only red in the  face, but spoke as hoarse as a crow, and his voice shook too, like a  taut ropeSilver, says he, youre old, and youre honest, or has the  name for it; and youve money too, which lots of poor sailors hasnt;  and youre brave, or Im mistook.
Silver, sir, returned the captain; hes as anxious as you and I to  smother things up.
Silver, if you like, cried the squire; but as for that intolerable  humbug, I declare I think his conduct unmanly, unsailorly, and downright  unEnglish.
Silver, though he was almost  killed already with fatigue, was set to an oar, like the rest of us, and  we were soon skimming swiftly over a smooth sea.

ben,.sentence: Ben, in his long, lonely wanderings about the island, had found the  skeletonit was he that had rifled it; he had found the treasure; he  had dug it up (it was the haft of his pickaxe that lay broken in the  excavation); he had carried it on his back, in many weary journeys, from  the foot of the tall pine to a cave he had on the twopointed hill at  the northeast angle of the island, and there it had lain stored in  safety since two months before the arrival of the HISPANIOLA.
Ben, Ben, murmured Silver, to think as youve done me!

was.sentence: Was it cheese you said he had a fancy for?
Was that you drinking with him, Morgan?

dont.sentence: Dont you get sucking of  that bilge, John.
Dont you take on, sir, he said, shaking the squires hand.

pipe.sentence: Pipe up and let me hear it, or lay to.

bens.sentence: Bens a good runner; few  seamen run better than Ben.

youre.sentence: Youre too much of the  born favourite for me.
Youre a  pushing lad, to be sure.
Youre him that never bungled nothing, you woodenheaded lubber!
Youre less of a fool  than many, take you all round; but you dont appear to me to have the  rudiments of a notion of the rules of health.
Youre  his last card, and by the living thunder, John, hes yours!
Youre either my ships cookand then you were treated handsomeor  Capn Silver, a common mutineer and pirate, and then you can go hang!
Youre a lad, you are, but  youre as smart as paint.
Youre a good lad, Jim, he said; and youre all in a clove hitch,  aint you?
Youre a good boy, or Im mistook;  but youre ony a boy, all told.
Youre a  funny man, by your account; but youre over now, and youll maybe step  down off that barrel and help vote.
Youre doing well, my friend, he said to the fellow with the bandaged  head, and if ever any person had a close shave, it was you; your head  must be as hard as iron.
Youre a pretty  colour, certainly; why, your liver, man, is upside down.
Youre a good man and a true; I never  seen a better man!
Youre the man for bargains, aint you?
Youre a good boy in your line, Jim,  but I dont think you and mell go to sea again.
Youre the man to keep your word, we know that.

dooty.sentence: Dooty is dooty, to be  sure.
Dooty is dooty, says he, and right  he is.

arrow,.sentence: Arrow, I believe him thoroughly honest; some of the men are the  same; all may be for what I know.
Arrow, a brown old sailor with earrings in his ears and a  squint.
Arrow, Hunter, Joyce, the  doctor, and the squire were to occupy these six berths.
Arrow, first of all, turned out even worse than the captain had  feared.

show.sentence: Show him in, said the squire.

perhaps,.sentence: Perhaps, sir, you dont like the ship?

inquired.sentence: inquired the squire, very  angry, as I could see.

possibly,.sentence: Possibly, sir, you may not like your employer, either?

next,.sentence: Next,  you say you dont like the crew.
Next, said the captain, I learn we are going after treasurehear  it from my own hands, mind you.

trelawney).sentence: Trelawney) the  secret has been told to the parrot.

silvers.sentence: Silvers face was a picture; his eyes started in his head with wrath.

tell.sentence: Tell us, squire, when you see the match, and well  hold water.

like.sentence: Like  enough, to judge from the sound, his back was broken on the spot.

second.sentence: Second  point, we have time before usat least until this treasures found.

otherwise.sentence: Otherwise I would ask you to let me resign.

doctor,.sentence: Doctor, said I, I passed my word.
Doctor, I said, you might spare  me.
Doctor, you will take the door, he resumed.
Doctor, said the captain, you are smart.
Doctor,  I thought you had worn the kings coat!
Doctor, he went on in his usual tones, I was athinking of that,  knowing as how you had a fancy for the boy.
Doctor, when a mans steering as near the wind as  meplaying chuckfarthing with the last breath in his body, likeyou  wouldnt think it too much, mayhap, to give him one good word?
Doctor, Im no coward; no, not Inot SO much!

arrow.sentence: Arrow and the captain were to sleep  on deck in the companion, which had been enlarged on each side till you  might almost have called it a roundhouse.
Arrow got the strong waters that destroyed him.

easy.sentence: Easy all, Long John, cried Israel.

Easy with that,  meneasy, he ran on, to the fellows who were shifting the powder; and  then suddenly observing me examining the swivel we carried amidships,  a long brass nine, Here you, ships boy, he cried, out o that!

blandly.sentence: Blandly and the like,  coming off to wish him a good voyage and a safe return.
Blandly  was beginning to think of fitting out her consort.

drove.sentence: drove the bars before them with a will.

time.sentence: Time after time  he was ordered below in disgrace.

watch.sentence: Watch him as we pleased, we could do nothing to  solve it; and when we asked him to his face, he would only laugh if  he were drunk, and if he were sober deny solemnly that he ever tasted  anything but water.

aboard.sentence: Aboard ship he carried his crutch by a lanyard round his neck, to have  both hands as free as possible.

sit.sentence: Sit you down and hear the  news.

till.sentence: till you wondered that it was not out of  breath, or till John threw his handkerchief over the cage.

shes.sentence: Shes sailed with England,  the great Capn England, the pirate.
Shes been at Madagascar, and at  Malabar, and Surinam, and Providence, and Portobello.

stand.sentence: Stand by to go about, the parrot would scream.

there,.sentence: There, John would  add, you cant touch pitch and not be mucked, lad.
There,  right behind me, was the glow of the campfire.

shell.sentence: Shell lie a point nearer the wind than a man  has a right to expect of his own married wife, sir.

double.sentence: Double grog was going on the least excuse; there was duff on odd days,  as, for instance, if the squire heard it was any mans birthday, and  always a barrel of apples standing broached in the waist for anyone to  help himself that had a fancy.

flint.sentence: Flint was capn; I was quartermaster, along  of my timber leg.
Flint was, and he died of rum at Savannah.
Flint warnt the man to pick a seamans pocket; and the birds, I  guess, would leave it be.

taint.sentence: Taint earning now, its  saving does it, you may lay to that.
Taint much use for fools, you may lay to itthat, nor nothing,  cried Silver.
Taint much good now, is it?

old.sentence: Old Pew, as had lost  his sight, and might have thought shame, spends twelve hundred pound in  a year, like a lord in Parliament.

dicks.sentence: Dicks crossed his luck and  spoiled his Bible, and thats about all.

israel,.sentence: Israel, said Silver, your head aint much account, nor ever was.

split.sentence: Split my sides, Ive a sick heart  to sail with the likes of you!

whos.sentence: Whos the better man at that?

everybody.sentence: Everybody knowed you was a kind of a chapling, John; but theres others  as could hand and steer as well as you, said Israel.

put.sentence: Put a name on what youre at; you aint  dumb, I reckon.

billy.sentence: Billy  Bones was the mate; Long John, he was quartermaster; and they asked him  where the treasure was.
Billy was the man for that, said Israel.

right.sentence: Right before us, at the southern  end, we saw the wreck of a ship in the last stages of dilapidation.
Right in front of me, not half a mile away, I beheld the HISPANIOLA  under sail.
Right you were, Capn Smollett, replied Silver.
Right you are, said Silver; rough and ready.
Right you was, sir,  says he, to haul your wind and keep the weather of the island.
Right in front, the doctor was pursuing  his assailant down the hill, and just as my eyes fell upon him, beat  down his guard and sent him sprawling on his back with a great slash  across the face.

Right below it there was  an exceedingly small hollow of green turf, hidden by banks and a thick  underwood about kneedeep, that grew there very plentifully; and in the  centre of the dell, sure enough, a little tent of goatskins, like what  the gipsies carry about with them in England.
Right up there  is our line for the Pole Star and the jolly dollars.
Right you were, sir, replied Silver; and precious little odds which,  to you and me.

wait.sentence: Wait is what I say; but when the time comes, why, let her rip!

lets.sentence: Lets allow the men an afternoon ashore.
Lets have a go of the rum.

dick,.sentence: Dick, who had dropped behind us and now brought  up the rear, was babbling to himself both prayers and curses as his  fever kept rising.
Dick, said Silver, I trust you.

terrified.sentence: Terrified as I was, I could not help thinking to myself that this must  have been how Mr.

dick.sentence: Dick alone still held his Bible, and looked around him as he went, with  fearful glances; but he found no sympathy, and Silver even joked him on  his precautions.
Dick dont feel well, sir, said one.
Dick was gone but a little while, and during his absence Israel spoke  straight on in the cooks ear.
Dick had his Bible out and was praying volubly.

away.sentence: Away to the  southwest of us we saw two low hills, about a couple of miles apart,  and rising behind one of them a third and higher hill, whose peak was  still buried in the fog.

sharp.sentence: Sharp as must have  been his annoyance, Silver had the strength of mind to hide it.

leastways,.sentence: Leastways, none of us had looked out.
Leastways, if such was your intention as to enter and careen, and there  aint no better place for that in these waters.
Leastways, if you dont, I do; and I wait hereand Im  still your capn, mindtill you outs with your grievances and I reply;  in the meantime, your black spot aint worth a biscuit.

thank.sentence: Thank you kindly, sir, replied Long John, again saluting.
Thank ye kindly, doctor, says he.
Thank you, my man, said I, quite as if nothing had happened, for we  had all quietly made up our minds to treat him like one of ourselves.
Thank you, my man, says Captain Smollett.
Thank you, Jim, said he quite loudly, that was all I wanted to know,  as if he had asked me a question.
Thank you, sir, returned Joyce with the same quiet civility.

captain,.sentence: Captain, said the squire, the house is quite invisible from the ship.
Captain, said I, Trelawney is the dead shot.
Captain, said the doctor, with your permission, thats Silver.

hed.sentence: Hed look remarkably well from a yardarm, sir, returned the captain.

third.sentence: Third point, there are faithful hands.

greycoloured.sentence: Greycoloured woods covered a large part of the surface.

anderson.sentence: Anderson was in command  of my boat, and instead of keeping the crew in order, he grumbled as  loud as the worst.

mutiny,.sentence: Mutiny,  it was plain, hung over us like a thundercloud.

silver.sentence: Silver doubled his pace, digging away with the foot of his crutch  like one possessed; and next moment he and I had come also to a dead  halt.
Silver had two guns  slung about himone before and one behindbesides the great cutlass  at his waist and a pistol in each pocket of his squaretailed coat.
Silver struck the barrel with his open hand.
Silver suddenly sprang up, and supporting himself with a hand against  the wall: Now I give you warning, George, he cried.
Silver briefly agreed, and this emissary retired again, leaving us  together in the dark.
Silver took a whiff or two of his pipe with great composure and then ran  on again.

Silver himself appeared  less terrible in contrast with this creature of the woods, and I turned  on my heel, and looking sharply behind me over my shoulder, began to  retrace my steps in the direction of the boats.
Silver had thrown his hat beside him on the  ground, and his great, smooth, blond face, all shining with heat, was  lifted to the other mans in a kind of appeal.
Silver was the captain, and a mighty rebellious crew he had of it.
Silver was in the sternsheets in  command; and every man of them was now provided with a musket from some  secret magazine of their own.
Silver had terrible hard work getting up the knoll.

Silver leant back against the wall, his arms  crossed, his pipe in the corner of his mouth, as calm as though he had  been in church; yet his eye kept wandering furtively, and he kept the  tail of it on his unruly followers.
Silver paused, and I could see by the faces of George and his late  comrades that these words had not been said in vain.

Silver  was roundly accused of playing doubleof trying to make a separate  peace for himself, of sacrificing the interests of his accomplices and  victims, and, in one word, of the identical, exact thing that he was  doing.
Silver was a changed man once he was out there and had his back to his  friends and the block house; his cheeks seemed to have fallen in, his  voice trembled; never was a soul more dead in earnest.
Silver  trusted me; I passed my word, and back I go.

Silver hobbled, grunting, on his crutch; his nostrils stood out and  quivered; he cursed like a madman when the flies settled on his hot and  shiny countenance; he plucked furiously at the line that held me to  him and from time to time turned his eyes upon me with a deadly look.
Silver never moved; he watched them, very upright on his crutch, and  looked as cool as ever I saw him.

keep.sentence: Keep indoors, men, said the captain.

crawling.sentence: Crawling on all fours, I made steadily but slowly towards them, till at  last, raising my head to an aperture among the leaves, I could see clear  down into a little green dell beside the marsh, and closely set about  with trees, where Long John Silver and another of the crew stood face to  face in conversation.

mate,.sentence: Mate, he was saying, its because I thinks gold dust of yougold  dust, and you may lay to that!

alls.sentence: Alls  well with him; no fear for a hand thats been shot down in his duty to  captain and owner.
Alls upyou cant make  nor mend; its to save your neck that Im aspeaking, and if one of the  wild uns knew it, whered I be, Tomnow, tell me, whered I be?

tom.sentence: Tom had leaped at the sound, like a horse at the spur, but Silver had  not winked an eye.

youve.sentence: Youve a head upon your shoulders, John,  and no mistake.
Youve neither sense  nor memory, and I leave it to fancy where your mothers was that let you  come to sea.
Youve little enough powder  already, my lads.
Youve seen my snuffbox, havent you?
Youve  broken your trust; youve lived in sin and lies and blood; theres a man  you killed lying at your feet this moment, and you ask me why!
Youve gone and  cut this out of a Bible.
Youve seen em, maybe, hanged in chains,  birds about em, seamen pinting em out as they go down with the tide.

kill.sentence: Kill me, if you please, or spare me.
Kill me too, if you can.
Kill another and do yourselves no good, or spare me and  keep a witness to save you from the gallows.

everything.sentence: Everything else was unchanged, the sun still shining mercilessly on the  steaming marsh and the tall pinnacle of the mountain, and I could scarce  persuade myself that murder had been actually done and a human life  cruelly cut short a moment since before my eyes.

goodbye.sentence: Goodbye to the HISPANIOLA; goodbye to the squire, the  doctor, and the captain!

mingled.sentence: Mingled with these were a few scattered pines, some fifty,  some nearer seventy, feet high.

ben.sentence: Ben Gunns not here  in the body any moren Flint.
Ben Gunn, he answered, and his voice sounded hoarse and awkward,  like a rusty lock.
Ben  Gunns last words came back to my mind.
Ben Gunn was on deck alone, and as soon as we came on board he began,  with wonderful contortions, to make us a confession.

marooned.sentence: Marooned three years agone, he continued, and lived on goats since  then, and berries, and oysters.

wherever.sentence: Wherever a man is, says I, a man can  do for himself.

boys,.sentence: Boys, said I, heres Flints treasure; lets land and find  it.

twelve.sentence: Twelve days they looked for it, and every day they had  the worse word for me, until one fine morning all hands went aboard.

left,.sentence: Left, left, says he; keep to your left hand, mate Jim!

theers.sentence: Theers where I killed my first goat.

waiting.sentence: Waiting was a strain, and it was decided that Hunter and I should go  ashore with the jollyboat in quest of information.

hunter.sentence: Hunter  brought the boat round under the sternport, and Joyce and I set to work  loading her with powder tins, muskets, bags of biscuits, kegs of pork, a  cask of cognac, and my invaluable medicine chest.
Hunter was steady, that we knew; Joyce  was a doubtful casea pleasant, polite man for a valet and to brush  ones clothes, but not entirely fitted for a man of war.
Hunter lay beside his  loophole, stunned; Joyce by his, shot through the head, never to move  again; while right in the centre, the squire was supporting the captain,  one as pale as the other.

hands,.sentence: Hands, who was not so far up, was in consequence  nearer to the ship and fell between me and the bulwarks.
Hands, but not the spirit; you must know  that already, I replied.
Hands, if possible, said the captain.
Hands, he said, here are two of us with a brace of pistols each.
Hands, said I, and Ill blow your brains out!

cries.sentence: Cries and confusion, the flashes and reports of pistolshots,  and one loud groan rang in my ears.

joyce.sentence: Joyce and I got out through the sternport,  and we made for shore again as fast as oars could take us.

lillibullero.sentence: Lillibullero  was dropped again; and just before we lost sight of them behind the  little point, one of them whipped ashore and disappeared.

pork,.sentence: Pork, powder, and biscuit was the  cargo, with only a musket and a cutlass apiece for the squire and me  and Redruth and the captain.

voices.sentence: Voices were heard faintly halloaing in the  direction of the two gigs; and though this reassured us for Joyce and  Hunter, who were well to the eastward, it warned our party to be off.

redruth.sentence: Redruth retreated from his place in the gallery and dropped into the  boat, which we then brought round to the ships counter, to be handier  for Captain Smollett.

gray,.sentence: Gray, following close behind me, had cut down the big boatswain ere  he had time to recover from his last blow.

smollett,.sentence: Smollett, a little louder, I am leaving this ship,  and I order you to follow your captain.

add.sentence: Add to this double apprehension the mystery that still hung over the  behaviour of my friends, their unexplained desertion of the stockade,  their inexplicable cession of the chart, or harder still to understand,  the doctors last warning to Silver, Look out for squalls when you  find it, and you will readily believe how little taste I found in my  breakfast and with how uneasy a heart I set forth behind my captors on  the quest for treasure.
Add to that the powder, pork, and breadbags.

Add to this that Gray, the new man, had his face tied up in a bandage  for a cut he had got in breaking away from the mutineers and that poor  old Tom Redruth, still unburied, lay along the wall, stiff and stark,  under the Union Jack.

could.sentence: Could you pull a little stronger?

israel.sentence: Israel could move about, he was  now armed, and if he had been at so much trouble to get rid of me,  it was plain that I was meant to be the victim.
Israel was Flints gunner, said Gray hoarsely.

theyll.sentence: Theyll have a hot run, sir, returned the captain.

mine.sentence: Mine I had snatched from my knees and held over my head, by  a sort of instinct.

forty.sentence: Forty paces farther we came to the edge of the wood and saw the stockade  in front of us.

poor.sentence: Poor old fellow, he had not uttered one word of surprise, complaint,  fear, or even acquiescence from the very beginning of our troubles till  now, when we had laid him down in the loghouse to die.

tom,.sentence: Tom, said the squire, say you forgive me, wont you?
Tom, my man, said I, youre going home.

ball.sentence: Ball after ball flew  over or fell short or kicked up the sand in the enclosure, but they had  to fire so high that the shot fell dead and buried itself in the soft  sand.

volunteers.sentence: Volunteers to go and bring in pork.

gray.sentence: Gray not only saved his money, but being suddenly smit  with the desire to rise, also studied his profession, and he is now  mate and part owner of a fine fullrigged ship, married besides, and the  father of a family.
Gray and Ben Gunn came and  went with the boat, while the rest during their absences piled treasure  on the beach.
Gray and Hunter were the first to come forward.
Gray told me nothing, and I asked  him nothing; and whats more, I would see you and him and this whole  island blown clean out of the water into blazes first.

Gray and I were sitting together at the far end of the block house, to  be out of earshot of our officers consulting; and Gray took his pipe out  of his mouth and fairly forgot to put it back again, so thunderstruck  he was at this occurrence.

somebody.sentence: Somebody hailing us, said Hunter, who was on guard.

barring.sentence: Barring rum, his match were  never seen.

rum.sentence: Rum wouldnt  bring me there, where youre goingnot rum wouldnt, till I see your  born genleman and gets it on his word of honour.

good,.sentence: Good, said I, and now may I go?

precious.sentence: Precious sight, and reasons  of his own, says you.

reasons.sentence: Reasons of his own; thats the mainstay; as  between man and man.

wild.sentence: Wild horses wouldnt draw it from you?

away,.sentence: Away, near the mouth of the  river, a great fire was glowing among the trees, and between that point  and the ship one of the gigs kept coming and going, the men, whom I  had seen so gloomy, shouting at the oars like children.

tired.sentence: Tired  though we all were, two were sent out for firewood; two more were set to  dig a grave for Redruth; the doctor was named cook; I was put sentry at  the door; and the captain himself went from one to another, keeping up  our spirits and lending a hand wherever it was wanted.

so,.sentence: So, Jim, said the doctor sadly, here you are.
So, he added, if we are not all shot down first theyll be glad to  be packing in the schooner.
So, said he, heres Jim Hawkins, shiver my timbers!

lively,.sentence: Lively, now, my lad;  youll want it before youve done.

capn.sentence: Capn Smolletts a fine seaman, as Ill own up to  any day, but stiff on discipline.
Capn Silver, sir, to come on board and make terms, he shouted.

maybe.sentence: Maybe you dont count it  nothing to have a real college doctor to see you every dayyou, John,  with your head brokeor you, George Merry, that had the ague shakes  upon you not six hours agone, and has your eyes the colour of lemon peel  to this same moment on the clock?
Maybe you  thought you was capn here, perhaps.
Maybe you think we were all a sheet in the winds eye.

either.sentence: Either you come  aboard along of us, once the treasure shipped, and then Ill give you my  affydavy, upon my word of honour, to clap you somewhere safe ashore.
Either they were dead drunk or had deserted her,  I thought, and perhaps if I could get on board I might return the vessel  to her captain.

handsomer.sentence: Handsomer you couldnt look to get,  now you.

refuse.sentence: Refuse that, and youve  seen the last of me but musketballs.

bundle.sentence: Bundle out of this, please, hand over hand, and double  quick.

wholl.sentence: Wholl give me a hand up?

growling.sentence: Growling the foulest imprecations, he crawled  along the sand till he got hold of the porch and could hoist himself  again upon his crutch.

them.sentence: Them that diell be the lucky ones.

toss.sentence: Toss out the fire, said the captain; the chill is past, and we  mustnt have smoke in our eyes.

hunter,.sentence: Hunter, take the east  side, there.
Hunter, serve out a round of brandy  to all hands.

see,.sentence: See, and dont expose  yourself; keep within, and fire through the porch.

joyce,.sentence: Joyce, you stand by the west, my man.

jackets.sentence: Jackets and coats  were flung aside, shirts thrown open at the neck and rolled up to the  shoulders; and we stood there, each at his post, in a fever of heat and  anxiety.

did.sentence: Did any of you gentlemen want to have it out with ME?
Did he take that medicine, men?

squire.sentence: Squire and Gray fired  again and yet again; three men fell, one forwards into the enclosure,  two back on the outside.
Squire and I cooked outside in spite of the  danger, and even outside we could hardly tell what we were at, for  horror of the loud groans that reached us from the doctors patients.

out,.sentence: Out, lads, out, and fight em in the open!

someone.sentence: Someone was  close behind, I knew not whom.
Someone was singing, a dull, old, droning  sailors song, with a droop and a quaver at the end of every verse,  and seemingly no end to it at all but the patience of the singer.

round.sentence: Round she came, till she was broadside on to meround still till she  had covered a half and then two thirds and then three quarters of the  distance that separated us.

mechanically,.sentence: Mechanically, I obeyed, turned eastwards, and with my cutlass raised,  ran round the corner of the house.

*.sentence: *    *The mutineers were soon only eight in number, for the man shot by Mr.

andersons.sentence: Andersons ballfor it was Job that  shot him firsthad broken his shoulderblade and touched the lung, not  badly; the second had only torn and displaced some muscles in the calf.

doctor.sentence: Doctor  Livesey patched it up with plaster and pulled my ears for me into the  bargain.

behind.sentence: Behind me was the sea, in front the anchorage.

alongside.sentence: Alongside lay one of the gigs, Silver in the sternsheetshim I could  always recognizewhile a couple of men were leaning over the stern  bulwarks, one of them with a red capthe very rogue that I had seen  some hours before stridelegs upon the palisade.

apparently.sentence: Apparently they were  talking and laughing, though at that distanceupwards of a mileI  could, of course, hear no word of what was said.

night.sentence: Night had almost  come when I laid my hand on its rough sides.

certainly.sentence: Certainly he took no pains to hide his thoughts, and certainly I read  them like print.
Certainly I did not know her way.

oaths.sentence: Oaths flew like hailstones, and every now and  then there came forth such an explosion as I thought was sure to end  in blows.

gradually.sentence: Gradually my mind came back again, my pulses quieted  down to a more natural time, and I was once more in possession of  myself.

Gradually weariness grew upon me; a  numbness, an occasional stupor, fell upon my mind even in the midst of  my terrors, until sleep at last supervened and in my seatossed coracle  I lay and dreamed of home and the old Admiral Benbow.

Gradually the night fell blacker; it was all I could do to guide myself  even roughly towards my destination; the double hill behind me and the  Spyglass on my right hand loomed faint and fainter; the stars were few  and pale; and in the low ground where I wandered I kept tripping among  bushes and rolling into sandy pits.

haulbowline.sentence: Haulbowline Head and Mizzenmast Hill were at my elbow, the hill bare  and dark, the head bound with cliffs forty or fifty feet high and  fringed with great masses of fallen rock.

north.sentence: North  of Haulbowline Head, the land runs in a long way, leaving at low tide  a long stretch of yellow sand.

first,.sentence: First, youve made a hash of this cruiseyoull be  a bold man to say no to that.

First, moving with all care, I gradually baled out the coracle with my  seacap; then, getting my eye once more above the gunwale, I set myself  to study how it was she managed to slip so quietly through the rollers.

presently.sentence: Presently she began to fetch more  and more to the westward, so that I thought they had sighted me and were  going about in chase.

clumsy.sentence: Clumsy fellows, said I; they must still be drunk as owls.

immensely.sentence: Immensely tall she looked to me from my low station in the  coracle.

dozens.sentence: Dozens of empty bottles clinked together in corners to the rolling of  the ship.

certainly,.sentence: Certainly,  since the mutiny began, not a man of them could ever have been sober.

foraging.sentence: Foraging about, I found a bottle with some brandy left, for Hands; and  for myself I routed out some biscuit, some pickled fruits, a great bunch  of raisins, and a piece of cheese.

hands;.sentence: Hands; and by  your leave, Ill strike em.
Hands; and youll please regard me as your captain until further  notice.

id.sentence: Id have had you but for that there lurch, but I dont  have no luck, not I; and I reckon Ill have to strike, which comes hard,  you see, for a master mariner to a ships younker like you, Jim.
Id help you sail her up to Execution Dock, by thunder!

capn,.sentence: Capn, said he at length with that same uncomfortable smile, heres  my old shipmate, OBrien; spose you was to heave him overboard.

obrien.sentence: OBrien there is in another world, and may be  watching us.

howsomever,.sentence: Howsomever, sperrits dont reckon for much, by what  Ive seen.

cut.sentence: Cut me a junk o that, says he, for I havent no knife and hardly  strength enough, so be as I had.
Cut me a quid, asll likely be the last, lad, for Im for my long  home, and no mistake.

fine.sentence: Fine flat sand, never a cats paw, trees all around of it, and  flowers ablowing like a garding on that old ship.

wounded.sentence: Wounded as he was, it was wonderful how fast he could move, his grizzled  hair tumbling over his face, and his face itself as red as a red ensign  with his haste and fury.

indeed.sentence: Indeed my  courage had begun to rise so high that I allowed myself a few darting  thoughts on what would be the end of the affair, and while I saw  certainly that I could spin it out for long, I saw no hope of any  ultimate escape.

blow.sentence: Blow and all, I was the first afoot again, for Hands had got  involved with the dead body.

quick.sentence: Quick as  thought, I sprang into the mizzen shrouds, rattled up hand over hand,  and did not draw a breath till I was seated on the crosstrees.

sometimes,.sentence: Sometimes, by the quivering of the water, he  appeared to move a little, as if he were trying to rise.

oddly.sentence: Oddly  enough, that very shudder did the business.

obrien,.sentence: OBrien, though still quite a  young man, was very bald.

possibly.sentence: Possibly I might be blamed a bit for my truantry, but the  recapture of the HISPANIOLA was a clenching answer, and I hoped that  even Captain Smollett would confess I had not lost my time.

bring.sentence: Bring a torch, Dick, said Silver when my capture was thus assured.

hawkins;.sentence: Hawkins; HELL excuse you, you may lay to that.

through.sentence: Through all  this sneering talk, I was made to feel the threat of death that overhung  me, and my cheeks burned and my heart beat painfully in my breast.

lad,.sentence: Lad, said Silver, no ones apressing of you.

four,.sentence: Four, says he; four, and one of us  wounded.

cross.sentence: Cross me, and youll go where many a good mans gone before you,  first and last, these thirty year backsome to the yardarm, shiver  my timbers, and some by the board, and all to feed the fishes.

morgan.sentence: Morgan paused, but a hoarse murmur rose from the others.
Morgan  found a piece of gold.

praps.sentence: Praps you can understand King Georges English.

ax.sentence: Ax your pardon, sir, returned one of the men; youre pretty free with  some of the rules; maybe youll kindly keep an eye upon the rest.

theyre.sentence: Theyre long bones, and the hairs been yellow.
Theyre a nice lot, aint they?
Theyre going to throw me off.

ship.sentence: Ship gone, neck gonethats the  size of it.

understand.sentence: Understand me, Jim, he said, returning.

belay.sentence: Belay that talk, John Silver, he said.

second,.sentence: Second, you let the enemy out o this here  trap for nothing.

third,.sentence: Third, you wouldnt let us go at them upon the march.

elect.sentence: Elect whom you please to be your capn now; Im done with it.

george,.sentence: George, shake up your timbers, son, and help Dr.
George, I reckon youll  have to wait another turn, friend; and lucky for you as Im not a  revengeful man.

itll.sentence: Itll do to kiss the book on still, wont it?

top.sentence: Top o the morning to you, sir!

bright.sentence: Bright and early, to be sure;  and its the early bird, as the saying goes, that gets the rations.

weve.sentence: Weve quite a surprise for you too, sir, he continued.

because,.sentence: Because, you see, since I am mutineers doctor, or prison doctor as I  prefer to call it, says Doctor Livesey in his pleasantest way, I make  it a point of honour not to lose a man for King George (God bless him!

camp.sentence: Camp  in a bog, would you?

george.sentence: George Merry was at the door, spitting and spluttering over some  badtasted medicine; but at the first word of the doctors proposal he  swung round with a deep flush and cried No!

heaven.sentence: Heaven forgive them, said the doctor; tis the mutineers!

Heaven knows, I cannot find it in my heart to  blame you, but this much I will say, be it kind or unkind: when Captain  Smollett was well, you dared not have gone off; and when he was ill and  couldnt help it, by George, it was downright cowardly!

whip.sentence: Whip over, and well run for it.

rapidly.sentence: Rapidly I described to him my adventures, and he heard me out in  silence.

water.sentence: Water would have been little to their taste; a sailor  is not usually a good shot; and besides all that, when they were so  short of eatables, it was not likely they would be very flush of powder.

thence,.sentence: Thence, bending to our left, we began to ascend the slope towards the  plateau.

thickets.sentence: Thickets of green nutmegtrees were dotted here and there with  the red columns and the broad shadow of the pines; and the first mingled  their spice with the aroma of the others.

shout.sentence: Shout after shout came from him, and the others  began to run in his direction.

messmates,.sentence: Messmates, but if Flint was living, this would be a hot  spot for you and me.

deadaye,.sentence: Deadaye, sure enough hes dead and gone below, said the fellow with  the bandage; but if ever sperrit walked, it would be Flints.

dear.sentence: Dear  heart, but he died bad, did Flint!

fifteen.sentence: Fifteen Men were his only song, mates;  and I tell you true, I never rightly liked to hear it since.

sheer.sentence: Sheer above us rose the Spyglass, here dotted  with single pines, there black with precipices.

spyglass.sentence: Spyglass shoulder, I take it, means that lower pint  there.

thinkin.sentence: Thinkin o FlintI think it  wereas done me.

already.sentence: Already the others had begun to lend an ear to this  encouragement and were coming a little to themselves, when the same  voice broke out againnot this time singing, but in a faint distant  hail that echoed yet fainter among the clefts of the Spyglass.

striking,.sentence: Striking,  as we did, pretty near northwest across the island, we drew, on the  one hand, ever nearer under the shoulders of the Spyglass, and on the  other, looked ever wider over that western bay where I had once tossed  and trembled in the coracle.

shaken.sentence: Shaken as I was with these alarms, it was hard for me to keep up with  the rapid pace of the treasurehunters.

shouted.sentence: shouted Merry; and the foremost broke into  a run.

dig.sentence: Dig away, boys, said Silver with the coolest insolence; youll find  some pignuts and I shouldnt wonder.

mates,.sentence: Mates, says he, theres two of them alone there; ones the old  cripple that brought us all here and blundered us down to this; the  others that cub that I mean to have the heart of.

merry.sentence: Merry tumbled head foremost into the excavation; the  man with the bandage spun round like a teetotum and fell all his length  upon his side, where he lay dead, but still twitching; and the other  three turned and ran for it with all their might.

pretty.sentence: Pretty well, I thank ye, says you.

soon,.sentence: Soon, however, he saw that our party had the  start of him; and Ben Gunn, being fleet of foot, had been dispatched in  front to do his best alone.

never,.sentence: Never, I am sure, were people  gayer or happier.

therefore.sentence: Therefore the work was pushed on briskly.

english,.sentence: English, French, Spanish,  Portuguese, Georges, and Louises, doubloons and double guineas and  moidores and sequins, the pictures of all the kings of Europe for the  last hundred years, strange Oriental pieces stamped with what looked  like wisps of string or bits of spiders web, round pieces and square  pieces, and pieces bored through the middle, as if to wear them round  your necknearly every variety of money in the world must, I think,  have found a place in that collection; and for number, I am sure they  were like autumn leaves, so that my back ached with stooping and my  fingers with sorting them out.

day.sentence: Day after day this work went on; by every evening a fortune had been  stowed aboard, but there was another fortune waiting for the morrow; and  all this time we heard nothing of the three surviving mutineers.

ask.sentence: Ask your pardon, sir, you would be very wrong, quoth Silver.

oxen.sentence: Oxen and  wainropes would not bring me back again to that accursed island; and  the worst dreams that ever I have are when I hear the surf booming about  its coasts or start upright in bed with the sharp voice of Captain Flint  still ringing in my ears: Pieces of eight!
